awd_titl_txt: Connecting nuances of foreign status, professional networks, and higher education outcomes in STEM disciplines over time
awd_abstract_narration:
A team of researchers from Arizona State University, Georgia Institute of Technology, and the University of Arkansas will investigate factors affecting the retention of foreign STEM higher education faculty in the US and those factors leading to their being more productive members of the workforce and advancing STEM in this country. In an era of global competition for academic STEM talent, and despite the high representation of foreign STEM faculty in US post-secondary institutions, significant research and data gaps have limited our understanding of how multiple dimensions of foreign background and experience, professional and collaborative networks, and key faculty outcomes are related. This project will help to address gaps through syntheses and new analyses of existing datasets and the piloting of a novel survey. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports work that advances the fundamental research literature on STEM learning and training.

The study will advance research on foreign faculty by conceptualizing a broader notion of foreign status that goes beyond nationality of birth and education to include cultural characteristics, family composition and location, local community engagement, and international professional experience.  The project scope will focus on the analysis and integration of extant data, and in so doing make clearer the value and limitations of those datasets. Methodologically, the project will use an innovative social network design to collect and integrate various national datasets to capture and analyze the relationships among a) dimension of foreign status; b) professional network structure, cultural composition and resources; and c) work history, satisfaction, mobility, mentoring, and productivity, among others. The study will be conducted in three integrated parts: 1) expanded analysis of existing NSF-sponsored survey datasets to investigate how foreign status and network structure and outcomes are related; 2) collection, merging and analysis of extant scientist data to determine gaps and complementarities critical for longer-term data collection; and 3) initial data collection to develop new survey designs and validate new metrics.  Study findings will be relevant for the design of interventions to improve the integration, satisfaction, retention, and productivity of foreign faculty for the long term competitiveness of the nation.

por.por_cntn:
The U.S. academic STEM workforce is increasingly international, drawing faculty from around the world. Across the disciplines, this increased internationalization of faculty is most pronounced in STEM disciplines, with some comprised of almost half of faculty coming from outside the United States. International faculty make significant contributions to the U.S. science system as highly productive scholars, mentors of early career scholars, and collaborators in global and national research networks. Yet despite the increase in global competition for academic STEM talent and high representation of international STEM faculty in US post-secondary institutions, significant research and data gaps have limited our understanding about their diversity, networks and impact. Further, international faculty have often been studied as 'foreign-born' faculty, where foreign origin is the single characteristic of interest. This has resulted in limited inquiry into how intersectionality of diverse attributes of ethnicity, nativity, gender, race, family composition, socioeconomic status, etc. are connected with scientific careers and advancement, collaboration, mobility, productivity and other outcomes. Our overall goal was to explore the multidimensional concept of 'foreign background and experience' (FBE) for STEM faculty through new concepts and measures, and how they strengthened the opportunity to better understand related career and collaborative outcomes in the academic science community. Further, our study added clarity to understanding the value and limitations of existing data for the study of foreign-born faculty careers.

Our study drew from existing data sources to take advantage of currently available robust survey data sources that included foreign-born faculty, but had not given targeted attention to this population. Through this inquiry, we advanced a broader understanding of foreign status and foreign background and experience. This work has produced several conference presentations and posters, published journal articles, and a dissertation.  Topics have addressed visa status and career experiences, differences in mobility between foreign-board and mobile scientists, differences in network structures, the intersectional gender and nativity-based experiences and drivers of foreign-born faculty work-family conflicts, examination of how first-generation U.S. and foreign-born faculty navigate their careers and work environments, differences in productivity, among other topics.

In summary, the collective results of our work have shown that there is a rich and inadequately explored dimensions to the career experiences of foreign-born faculty in U.S. academic institutions. Further, because these FBE experiences do not always align with the findings from studies of women and other under-represented groups in the U.S., further work to understand FBE diversity and contributions to US science are needed. Our work has underscored this importance and can inform future studies.
